{{refimprove|date=May 2016}}
{{Infobox book | name = A Guide Book of United States Coins | image = Redbooksoftcover2019.png | image_size = | alt = Image of the Red Book of 2018, dated 2019, soft cover edition. | caption = 72nd edition of Red Book (2018, dated 2019) soft cover edition. | author = [[Richard S. Yeoman|Richard (R. S.) Yeoman]] | editor = Jeff Garrett | audio_read_by = | title_orig = | orig_lang_code = | title_working = | translator = | illustrator = | cover_artist = | country = [[United States]] | language = English | series = | release_number = | subject = [[Numismatics]] | genre = Antiques & Collectibles | set_in = | publisher = Whitman's Publishing LLC | publisher2 = | pub_date = November 1946 | english_pub_date = | published = | media_type = | pages = 464 | awards = | isbn = 978-0794845711 | isbn_note = | oclc = | dewey = | congress = | preceded_by = | followed_by = | native_wikisource = | wikisource = | notes = | exclude_cover = | website = }}
'''''A Guide Book of United States Coins (Red Book)''''', by [[Richard S. Yeoman|R. S. Yeoman]], is a [[pricing guide]] for [[Coinage of the United States|United States]] [[coin collecting|coin collectors]] and is considered one of the most authoritative coin price sources.
==Editorial== Editor [[R. S. Yeoman]] was the editor until he retired in 1970.
In 1971 his assistant, [[Kenneth Bressett]], took over as the editor of the Blue Book and Red Book until he retired in 2017.
In 2018 Jeff Garrett, former ANA president, took over and assumed the post as senior editor, and still holds that position.<ref>{{cite web |title=Jeff Garrett Named Senior Editor of Red Book |url=http://rarecoingallery.com/story/18 |website=Rarecoingallery.com |accessdate=November 12, 2018}}</ref>
Yeoman is still listed as the author of each edition of the books, and Bressett is listed as [[emeritus|editor emeritus]].
== Publication == The book is the longest running coin price guide. The first edition, dated 1947, went on sale November 1946.<ref name="coinworld2016">{{cite news|last=Tebben|first=Gerald|title=Looking at the 'Red Book' at age 70|magazine=[[Coin World]]|issn=0010-0447|issue=2928|date=May 23, 2016|pages=30–32}}</ref> After the first three editions (dated 1947, 1948, 1949), the ''Guide Book'' was not published in 1949; annual publication resumed in 1950 with the 4th edition (dated 1951–1952) and has continued to this day. The book's all-time peak print run for a single year was 1.2 million copies in 1965.<ref name="coinworld2016" /> The 70th edition, cover-dated 2017, was published in 2016.<ref name="coinworld2016" />
The ''Red Book'' lists the retail value of all United States coins from Colonial and pre-federal State Issues to all circulating issues, as well as commemorative and modern-day [[bullion coin]]s, as well as other significant U.S. [[Pattern coin|patterns]], private and territorial gold, [[Hard-times token]]s, Confederate issues, Hawaiian tokens and coins, Philippine issues and Alaskan tokens. It also shows Issue Prices and Current Values of [[mint set]]s and [[proof set]]s.
The values are divided by main [[Coin grading|coin grades]].
[[File:Redbookinside.jpg|thumb|alt=Inside page.|Example inside page of the Red Book showing the [[Walking Liberty half dollar]]]] == Name == The ''Guide Book'' got its ''Red Book'' nickname due to the book's solid red cover.
== Formats == In addition to the traditional hardcover edition, new formats have been added through the years: * Softcover (perfect bound) – 1993–1996, 1998, 2003–2006. * Spiralbound softcover – 1997, 1999 to date. * Spiralbound hardcover – 2008 to date. * Large-print edition – 8x10, spiralbound softcover – 2010. * LE Leatherbound – 2009 to date. Each year the publisher prints fewer copies than the previous year. (2015 was limited to only 500 copies; in years past they've printed 3,000 copies and those sold out very quickly) * MEGA red - only 4 editions were printed, latest in 2018, dated 2019.
Early editions of the ''Red Book'' are collectible. The first edition has commanded $1,500 or more on the open market. The ''Red Book'' has its own ''Red Book'' – '''''A Guide Book Of The Official Red Book Of United States Coins''''' by [[Frank J. Colletti]] published 2009 by Whitman Publishing ({{ISBN|978-0-7948-2580-5}}).
A facsimile of the 1947 edition was published in 2006, on the 60th anniversary of the publication of the first edition. Dubbed the "1947 Tribute Edition" ({{ISBN|0-7948-2230-4}}), it differs from the original by having a dust jacket (the first ''Red Book'' ever to have one) and an additional 32-page color section, comparing the coin collecting hobby in 1946 and 2006. Except for the dust jacket and color section, it was an exact replica of the first printing (with the phrase "scarcity of this date" on page 135).
==References== {{reflist}}
==See also== * ''[[Standard Catalog of World Coins]]''

{{Infobox artwork | title = Alan Turing statue | other_language_1 = | other_title_1 = | other_language_2 = | other_title_2 = | image = File:Alan Turing by Stephen Kettle 2007.jpg | image_size = 240px | alt = | caption = View of the statue on exhibit at [[Bletchley Park]] | artist = [[Stephen Kettle]] | catalogue = | year = {{start date|2007}} | completion_date = <!-- For a more specific date (post-1583): {{start date|YYYY|MM|DD|df=y}} --> | type = Sculpture | material = [[Slate]] | subject = [[Alan Turing]] | height_metric = <!-- (i.e. in metric units) --> | width_metric = | length_metric = | diameter_metric = | height_imperial = | width_imperial = | length_imperial = | diameter_imperial = | dimensions = | dimensions_ref = | metric_unit = m <!-- Note: this parameter must either use the value given or not be included --> | imperial_unit = ft <!-- Note: this parameter must either use the value given or not be included --> | condition = | city = [[Bletchley]], near [[Milton Keynes]], [[England]] | museum = [[Bletchley Park]] | accession = 2007 | coordinates = {{coord|51.997435|-0.741160|display=inline,title}} | pushpin_map = Buckinghamshire | pushpin_map_caption = Location at Bletchley Park | pushpin_label_position = | owner = [[Bletchley Park Trust]] (commissioned by [[Sidney Frank]]) | preceded_by = <!-- preceding work by the same artist --> | followed_by = <!-- next work by the same artist --> | website = {{URL|https://www.stephenkettle.co.uk/turing.html}} }} The '''''Alan Turing''''' statue, created in [[slate]] by [[Stephen Kettle]] in 2007, is located at [[Bletchley Park]] in [[England]] as part of an exhibition on [[Alan Turing]].<ref name="kettle">{{cite web| url=https://www.stephenkettle.co.uk/turing.html | title=Alan Turing | first=Stephen | last=Kettle | authorlink=Stephen Kettle | website=www.stephenkettle.co.uk | location=UK | accessdate=20 August 2018 }}</ref><ref>[[Simon Greenish|Greenish, Simon]]. [[Jonathan Bowen|Bowen, Jonathan]], [[Jack Copeland|Copeland, Jack]], Chapter 19, ''Turing's monument'', page 196. In {{cite book |author-link1 = Jack Copeland|last1 = Copeland | first1=B. Jack | authorlink2=Jonathan Bowen | last2=Bowen | first2=Jonathan P. | authorlink3=Robin Wilson (mathematician)| last3=Wilson | first3=Robin | | last4=Sprevak | first4=Mark | title=[[The Turing Guide]] | publisher=[[Oxford University Press]] | year=2017 | isbn=978-0198747826 }}</ref> It was commissioned by the American businessman and philanthropist [[Sidney Frank]] (1919–2006).<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.geograph.org.uk/photo/1591025 | title=SP8634: Alan Turing Statue at Bletchley Park | publisher=[[Geograph]] | location=UK | accessdate=3 September 2018 }}</ref>
The slate for the sculpture was selected from [[North Wales]] because the sculptor learned that Turing used to holiday there as a child and adult.<ref name="kettle" /> The slate originated from [[Llechwedd quarry|Llechwedd]], near [[Blaenau Ffestiniog]]. Turing is depicted seated and looking at a German [[Enigma machine]]. He is dressed in a jacket, but there is some deliberate untidiness in his clothing.
In 2007, it was commented that the statue acknowledges Turing as a [[Cryptanalysis|codebreaker]] but not as a [[gay icon]].<ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/artblog/2007/jun/19/theenigmaofalanturing | first=Richard | last=Smith | title=The enigma of Alan Turing | work=Art & design blog | publisher=[[The Guardian]] | date=19 June 2007 | accessdate=20 August 2018 }}</ref> The statue became part of a new exhibition at Bletchley Park on Alan Turing in 2012, the centenary year of Turing's birth.<ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.theregister.co.uk/2012/03/06/new_turing_exhibition_bletchley_park/ | first=Brid-Aine | last=Parnell | title=Bletchley Park gets personal with new Alan Turing exhibition | work=Science | publisher=[[The Register]] | location=UK | date=6 March 2012 | accessdate=20 August 2018 }}</ref> Sir [[John Dermot Turing]], nephew of Alan Turing, attended the opening of the exhibition and posed with the statue.<ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-beds-bucks-herts-17262062 | title=Alan Turing exhibition opens at Bletchley Park | work=[[BBC News]] | publisher=[[BBC]] | location=UK | date=7 March 2007 | accessdate=20 August 2018 }}</ref>
==See also== * [[2007 in art]] * ''[[Alan Turing Memorial]]'' (2001), Manchester * [[List of LGBT monuments and memorials]]

{{infobox Museum |name = Alfercam Museum |image = |map_type = |map_caption = |coordinates = {{coord|43.559225|-5.933808|display=inline}} |established = 15 December 2006 |location = Calle José Cueto 60
33400 Avilés, Spain |visitors = |director = |publictransit = |website = http://www.museoalfercam.com }} '''Alfercam Museum''' ({{es icon}}: '''Museo Alfercam''') is a music and automobile [[museum]] in [[Avilés]], [[Asturias]], [[Spain]]. Its name is a combination of the owners' names: '''Al'''fredo and '''Fer'''nando '''Cam'''pelo. Established 15 December 2006, it was Aviles' first museum and was open Wednesday through Sunday. It closed temporally 19 November 2008 due to financial losses.{{cite web|url=https://translate.google.com/translate?hl=en&sl=es&u=http://www.elcomerciodigital.com/aviles/20081217/aviles/museo-alfercam-unico-ciudad-20081217.html&ei=I052SpnkE4eAswPK-tHMCA&sa=X&oi=translate&resnum=9&ct=result&prev=/search%3Fq%3D%2522Museo%2BAlfercam%2522%26hl%3Den%26client%3Dfirefox-a%26rls%3Dorg.mozilla:en-US:official%26hs%3DODT|title=Alfercam Museum, the only one of the city, closed its doors after two years of activity|publisher=ElComercioDigital.com|access-date=3 August 2009}} Later it was open again. The over {{convert|1000|sqft|sqm|abbr=on}} space exhibits the collections of the Campelo brothers.{{cite web|url=https://translate.google.com/translate?hl=en&sl=es&u=http://www.vivirasturias.com/asturias/aviles/museo-alfercam-de-instrumentos-musicales-etnicos-y-automocion-clasica/es&ei=I052SpnkE4eAswPK-tHMCA&sa=X&oi=translate&resnum=6&ct=result&prev=/search%3Fq%3D%2522Museo%2BAlfercam%2522%26hl%3Den%26client%3Dfirefox-a%26rls%3Dorg.mozilla:en-US:official%26hs%3DODT|title=Museum Alfercam of ethnic musical instruments and automotive classic|access-date=3 August 2009}} One of the exhibit halls showcases approximately 400 [[Ethnic group|ethnic]] [[musical instrument]]s while the second contains 30 [[classic car]]s. == See also == * [[List of music museums]] ==References== {{Reflist}} [[Category:Avilés]] [[Category:Automotive museums]] [[Category:Defunct museums]] [[Category:Museums established in 2006]] [[Category:Museums in Asturias]] [[Category:Music museums]] [[Category:Organizations disestablished in 2008]] [[Category:Music organizations based in Spain]] {{Asturias-stub}} {{Spain-museum-stub}}

revision.text:
{{refimprove|date=April 2010}} The '''Allsport''' photography agency was started in 1968 by sports photographer Tony Duffy. It grew to become arguably the most highly respected sport photo agency in the world, and its photographers won numerous awards until acquisition by [[Getty Images]] in 1998.
Until 1968 Tony Duffy was an accountant and part-time photographer who shot [[track and field athletics]] in his spare time. He paid for himself to go to the [[1968 Summer Olympics|1968 Olympic Games]] in Mexico City.
At the 1968 Olympic Games, [[Bob Beamon]] broke the World Record in the Long Jump with a leap of 8m 90 or 29 ft 2½ inches. Crouched at the end of the long jump pit was Tony Duffy. Duffy took a picture which, through wide re-production, is perhaps the definitive shot of this remarkable jump.<ref>{{cite web|author=Rosenbaum, Mike |url=http://trackandfield.about.com/od/longjump/ss/illuslongjump_3.htm|title= An Illustrated History of the Long Jump|accessdate=20 April 2011 }}</ref> The Allsport agency was founded on the strength of his photograph of Beamon.
==1970s==
Tony Duffy was joined in the 1970s by photographers John Starr, Don Morley, and in 1971, Steve Powell. Powell would go on to become Group Managing Director. Morley specialised in shooting [[motorsport]], specifically motorbikes, and Starr took studio shots. Adrian Murrell joined in the mid seventies and became the agency's [[Cricket]] specialist. Duffy's innovative feature 'Sport and the Body' brought his name and the name of the agency to a wider audience when published by the Sunday Times in 1973. The use of naked sports stars caused uproar and brought nationwide publicity.
==1980s==
The Allsport agency experienced tremendous growth throughout the 1980s, and in 1983 Tony Duffy moved to California to open the Allsport USA offices in Santa Monica. In 1985 he was joined by Mike Powell, the younger brother of Steve. David Cannon joined in 1982 as a general sport photographer specialising in [[association football|football]] and [[golf]]. With Duffy working stateside, Bob Martin assumed the role of leading athletics photographer in Europe. Younger photographers such as Mike King, Simon Bruty, Gray Mortimore, Mike Stahlschmidt, Jonathan Daniel and Pascal Rondeau continued to create stunning and thought-provoking sport images.
In 1988 Allsport was appointed as Official Photographer to the International Olympic Committee. The first book in the Visions of Sport series was published to celebrate 20 years of Allsport, and included all of the famous images shot by Allsport photographers in its first 20 years.
== References == {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Photography organizations]] [[Category:Stock photography]] [[Category:Getty Images]]

{{Infobox museum | name = Amsterdam City Archives | native_name = Stadsarchief Amsterdam | native_name_lang = Dutch | image = File:Gebouw de Bazel.jpg | image_upright = 1.15 | caption = [[De Bazel]], home of the Amsterdam City Archives | alt = | map_type = Netherlands Amsterdam Central | map_size = 250 | map_caption = Location within the city center of Amsterdam. | coordinates = {{coord|52.3646|4.8923|type:landmark_region:NL-NH|display=inline,title}} | established = | dissolved = | location = Vijzelsraat 32,
[[Amsterdam]], [[Netherlands]] | type = [[archive]] | collection = | visitors = 130,154 (2014) [http://amsterdam.toeristischebarometer.nl/Module/Index/0?year=2014&focusedChartType=1], Toeristiche Barometer, 2015. Retrieved on 6 October 2015. | director = | president = | curator = | publictransit = | car_park = | network = | website = {{URL|https://www.amsterdam.nl/stadsarchief/}} {{du icon}} }} The '''Amsterdam City Archives''' ({{lang-nl|Stadsarchief Amsterdam}}) preserves documents pertaining to the history of [[Amsterdam]] and provides information about the city. With archives covering a shelf-length of about 50 kilometres,"[https://www.amsterdam.nl/stadsarchief/organisatie/bedrijfsprofiel/ Bedrijfsprofiel Stadsarchief Amsterdam]" {{du icon}} [archives profile], 20 March 2017. City of Amsterdam. www.amsterdam.nl/stadsarchief. Retrieved 8 June 2017. the Amsterdam City Archives is the largest municipal archive in the world. ==History== In the Middle Ages, Amsterdam’s important documents were stored in a special cabinet that was kept in the so-called ‘Iron Chapel’ (IJzeren Kapel) in the Old Church ([[Oude Kerk (Amsterdam)|Oude Kerk]]).P. Scheltema, ''Het archief der ijzeren kapel in de Oude of Sint Nikolaas kerk te Amsterdam'', Amsterdam 1850. In the nineteenth century, the archives moved to the Waag building at the [[Nieuwmarkt]], and in 1914 to the [[former town hall of Nieuwer-Amstel]]. Since the summer of 2007, the Amsterdam City Archives have been located in the monumental building [[De Bazel]], in the city-centre, which derives its name from the famous Dutch architect K.P.C. de Bazel, who designed it.''De Bazel: tempel aan de Vijzelstraat in Amsterdam'', Mariëlle Hageman, Stefanie van Odenhoven and Ludger Smit eds., Bussum 2007. ==Preservation== The Amsterdam City Archives belongs to the [[government of Amsterdam]]. It preserves the archives of the municipal government and of the national government when related to Amsterdam, besides those of private institutions, families or individuals, and companies connected with the city. The municipalities of [[Ouder-Amstel]] and [[Amstelveen]] have also deposited their historical archives at the Amsterdam City Archives. In addition, the City Archives houses a large collection of images and audio-visual material, as well as a library. Among the various documents of international significance kept at the Amsterdam City Archives are the archives of the [[Heineken]] brewery and the renowned [[Concertgebouw]], letters written by [[Charles Darwin]] and [[Mahatma Gandhi]], an eighteenth-century trade agreement between the city and the newly founded [[United States of America]], the book containing the excommunication of seventeenth-century philosopher [[Spinoza]], and a police report about the theft of [[Anne Frank]]’s bike, dated April 13, 1942. The Amsterdam City Archives also monitors the way the various departments within Amsterdam’s administrative structure manage their archives, ensuring that documents that are of significance for the city’s history are maintained. ==Publication== Archival material is made available for consultation both on site and through the internet. In recent years, many documents have been digitized. The website of the Amsterdam City Archives features an Image Bank, containing more than 260.000 photos, drawings, and prints related to the city, and an Archives Database, providing scans of archival material on request, including a wealth of sources for genealogical research, accessible through several indexes. These scans now number more than seven million.''Stadsarchief in beweging: het Stadsarchief Amsterdam tussen 2006 en 2010'', Amsterdam 2006. The Amsterdam City Archives also shares the available expertise on Amsterdam and its history through publications and events. The Archives regularly presents temporary exhibitions, while noteworthy documents are on permanent display in the so-called Treasury (Schatkamer). Historical films about Amsterdam are shown in a small movie theatre. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * "[http://www.iamsterdam.com/en/visiting/what-to-do/museums-and-galleries/museums/amsterdam-city-archives Amsterdam City Archives]" on official city of Amsterdam portal website in English, www.iamsterdam.com {{Authority control}} [[Category:Archives in the Netherlands]] [[Category:History museums in the Netherlands]] [[Category:Museums in Amsterdam]] [[Category:City archives]]

This is a partial list of [[Anton Chekhov]]'s works: [[File:Anton Tschechow - Ölskizze von Lewitan.jpg|thumb|250px|Portrait of Chekhov by [[Isaak Levitan]] 1886]]
== Plays == *''That Worthless Fellow Platonov'' (most commonly known as ''Пьеса без названия'' ['Untitled play'] or simply, ''[[Platonov (play)|Platonov]]''; c. 1881)—provided the source material for Michael Frayn's ''[[Wild Honey (play)|Wild Honey]]'' *''[[On the Harmful Effects of Tobacco]]'' (''О вреде табака''; 1886, 1902) *''Swansong'' (''Лебединая песня'', 1887)—one-act play *''[[Ivanov (play)|Ivanov]]'' (''Иванов'', 1887)—a drama in four acts *''[[The Bear (play)|The Bear]]'' or ''The Boor'' (''Медведь: Шутка в одном действии'', 1888)—one act comedy *''[[A Marriage Proposal]]'' (''Предложение'', c. 1888-1889)—one act *''[[A Tragedian in Spite of Himself]]'' or ''A Reluctant Tragic Hero'' (''Трагик поневоле'', 1889) *''[[The Wedding (Chekhov play)|The Wedding]]'' (''Свадьба'', 1889)—one act *''[[Tatiana Repina]]'' (''Татьяна Репина'', 1889)—one act *''[[The Wood Demon (play)|The Wood Demon]]'' (''Леший'', 1889)—four-act comedy *''The Festivities'' (''Юбилей'', 1891) *''[[The Seagull]]'' (''Чайка'', 1896)—a comedy in four acts *''[[Uncle Vanya]]'' (''Дядя Ваня'', 1899-1900)—based on ''The Wood Demon'' *''[[Three Sisters (play)|Three Sisters]]'' (''Три сестры'', 1901)—a drama in four acts *''[[The Cherry Orchard]]'' (''Вишнёвый сад'', 1904)—a comedy in four acts * [[On the High Road]] one act (1884).

revision.text:
'''Biodiesel''' has a number of '''standards''' for its quality.
{{main|Biodiesel}}
[[Image:Biodiesel.JPG|thumb|Biodiesel sample]]
The European standard for biodiesel is [[EN 14214]], which is translated into the respective national standards for each country that forms the [[European Committee for Standardization|CEN]] (European Committee for Standardization) area e.g., for the United Kingdom, [[British Standards|BS]] EN 14214 and for Germany [[DIN]] EN 14214. It may be used outside the CEN area as well. The main difference that exists between EN 14214 standards of different countries is the national annex detailing climate related requirements of biodiesel in different CEN member countries.
Other international standards published by [[ASTM International]] include: * [[ASTM D6751|D6751]]-08 Specification for Biodiesel Fuel Blend Stock (B100) for Middle Distillate Fuels * D975-08a Specification for Diesel Fuel Oils (on and off-road applications) * D396-08b Specification for Fuel Oils (home heating and boiler applications) * D7467-08 Specification for Diesel Fuel Oil, Biodiesel Blend (B6 to B20)
There are also [[DIN]] standards for three different varieties of biodiesel, which are made of different oils: *RME ([[rapeseed]] methyl [[ester]], according to DIN E 51606) *PME (vegetable methyl ester, purely vegetable products, according to DIN E 51606) *FME (fat methyl ester, vegetable and animal products, according to DIN V 51606)
The National Standards of Canada for biodiesel are published by the Canadian General Standards Board (CGSB):<ref>http://www.tpsgc-pwgsc.gc.ca/ongc-cgsb/publications/catalogue/index-eng.html.</ref> *CAN/CGSB-3.520 Diesel Fuel Containing Low Levels of Biodiesel (B1 - B5) *CAN/CGSB-3.522 Diesel Fuel Containing Biodiesel (B6-B20) *CAN/CGSB-3.524 Biodiesel (B100) for Blending in Middle Distillate Fuels
The standards ensure that the following important factors in the fuel production process are satisfied: *Acid value *Complete reaction. *Removal of [[glycerin]]. *Removal of [[catalyst]]. *Removal of [[alcohol]]. *Absence of [[Fatty acid#Free fatty acids|free fatty acids]]. *Low [[sulfur]] content. *Cold Filter Plugging point *Cloud Point
Basic industrial tests to determine whether the products conform to the standards typically include [[Chromatography#Gas chromatography|gas chromatography]], a test that verifies only the more important of the variables above. Tests that are more complete are more expensive. Fuel meeting the quality standards is very non-toxic, with a toxicity rating ({{LD50}}) of greater than 50 mL/kg.
==ASTM B20 ==
[[ASTM International]] has approved a new specification for diesel fuel blends containing 6%-20% biodiesel. According to the [[National Biodiesel Board]] (NBB), ASTM standards for the 20% biodiesel blends, or B20, are a crucial hurdle for the full acceptance of the use of such blends in diesel vehicles. In 2008, ASTM published new Biodiesel Blend Specifications.<ref>[http://nbb.grassroots.com/09Releases/ASTMBlend/ National Biodiesel Board Press Release 10/14/08] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081216020822/http://nbb.grassroots.com/09Releases/ASTMBlend/ |date=2008-12-16 }}</ref>
With the new specification in place, automakers and engine manufacturers can test B20 in their diesel engines and know that consumers will be fueling their vehicle with a fuel of the same quality. Currently, Chrysler LLC supports the use of B20 in its Dodge Ram diesel pickups, but only for use in fleets. Likewise, General Motors Corporation accepts the use of 5% biodiesel blends, or B5, in all its vehicles, but limits the use of B20 to special equipment options available only to government fleets in a limited selection of vehicles. While setting the new B20 standard, ASTM International also made changes to its specifications for B5 and for 100% biodiesel, or B100.<ref>[http://www.eere.energy.gov/news/enn.cfm#id_11838 EERE News: EERE Network News<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
The FTC will require pumps with biodiesel blends to carry a blue label, while biomass-based diesel blends will carry an orange label. The somewhat confusing "small print" was required by the energy act. Credit: Federal Trade Commission
Engine warranty concerns also came into play in a recent effort to create labeling requirements for diesel fuels containing renewable fuel blends. The Energy Independence and Security Act of 2007 requires the Federal Trade Commission (FTC) to set labeling requirements that address the blending of biodiesel and other types of biomass-based diesel fuels into diesel fuel. Some companies are converting biomass such as animal fats directly into a liquid with the properties of diesel fuel, a product that blurs the lines between biodiesel and diesel fuel. At first, the FTC proposed to treat all renewable diesel fuels the same, but the NBB warned that not all biomass-based diesel fuels would necessarily meet the ASTM standards required by automakers for diesel fuels. On the other hand, biomass-based diesel fuels that meet ASTM standards could be used in much higher concentrations than biodiesel, which is usually limited to 20% biodiesel blends for standard diesel vehicles. Considering those comments, the FTC decided to set separate labeling requirements for biodiesel blends and biomass-based diesel fuel blends.
==References== {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Biodiesel]] [[Category:Standards]]

revision.text:
{{Orphan|date=August 2012}}
'''''Cape Town & District Gas, Light & Coke Co, Ltd v Director of Valuations'''''<ref>1949 (4) SA 197 (C).</ref> is an important case in [[South African law]]. It was heard in the Cape Provincial Division by De Villiers JP and Searle J on August 5, 1949, with judgment on August 30. P. Charles appeared for the appellant and HG Lawrence KC for the respondent.
== Facts == In 1903, the appellant company had built, on a concrete foundation sunk four feet below surface level, a heavy steel structure for the purpose
# of storing gas generated in a building some distance from it; and # of supplying such gas for consumption to the public.
The gas holder was not affixed to the soil by any mechanical means; its affixation was entirely due to its sheer weight resting upon the concrete foundation. It appeared that the company intended using it as long as it continued to function efficiently.
== Judgment == In an appeal under section 67 of Ordinance 26 of 1944 (Cape), the court held that the [[gasometer]] was [[immovable property]]. The court held further that it was a "structural improvement" within section 45(h) of the Ordinance, although ''[[quaere]]'' whether the structure was also a "building" within the meaning of sub-section (b) of section 45.
== See also == * [[Immovable property]] * [[Law of South Africa]] * [[South African property law]]
== References ==
=== Case law === * ''Cape Town & District Gas, Light & Coke Co, Ltd v Director of Valuations'' 1949 (4) SA 197 (C).
== Notes == {{Reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Cape Town and District Gas, Light and Coke v Director of Valuations}} [[Category:1949 in South African law]] [[Category:1949 in case law]] [[Category:Western Cape Division cases]]

revision.text: {{lowercase}} {{Infobox Software | name = cd / chdir | logo = | screenshot = Plan 9 from Bell Labs (process management).png | screenshot size = | caption = The {{code|cd}} command in an [[rc]] session running on [[Plan 9 from Bell Labs]] | developer = [[Digital Research]], [[MetaComCo]], [[Microsoft]], [[Hewlett-Packard]], [[JP Software]], ReactOS Contributors | released = | latest release version = | latest release date = | operating system = [[Unix]], [[Unix-Like]], [[DOS]], [[FlexOS]], [[OS/2]], [[TRIPOS]], [[Microsoft Windows]], [[HP Multi-Programming Executive|MPE/iX]], [[ReactOS]], [[KolibriOS]], [[SymbOS]], [[DexOS]] | genre = [[Command (computing)|Command]] | license = | website = }} The '''{{code|cd}}''' command, also known as '''{{code|chdir}}''' ('''ch'''ange '''dir'''ectory), is a [[Command-line interface|command-line]] [[operating system shell|OS shell]] command used to change the current [[working directory]] in [[operating system]]s such as [[Unix]], [[DOS]], [[OS/2]], [[TRIPOS]]https://www.pagetable.com/docs/amigados_tripos/tripos_manuals.pdf, [[AmigaOS]]https://archive.org/details/1988-rugheimer-spanik-amigados-quick-reference (where if a bare [[Path (computing)|path]] is given, cd is ''implied''), [[Microsoft Windows]], [[ReactOS]], and [[Linux]]. It can be used in [[shell script]]s and [[batch file]]s. The command is also available in the [[Open-source software|open source]] [[MS-DOS]] [[emulator]] [[DOSBox]] and in the [[Unified Extensible Firmware Interface|EFI shell]].{{cite web | url = http://software.intel.com/en-us/articles/efi-shells-and-scripting/ | title = EFI Shells and Scripting | publisher = [[Intel]] | accessdate = 2013-09-25 }} The command is named {{code|chdir}} in [[HP Multi-Programming Executive|MPE/iX]].[http://www.teamnaconsulting.com/compresources/pdfs/c01687363.pdf MPE/iX Command Reference Manual] The [[system call]] that affects the command in most operating systems is {{code|chdir}} that is defined by [[POSIX]]. The command is analogous to the [[Stratus VOS|OpenVOS]] {{code|change_current_dir}} command.http://stratadoc.stratus.com/vos/19.1.0/r098-19/wwhelp/wwhimpl/common/html/r098-19.pdf ==Usage== A [[directory (file systems)|directory]] is a logical section of a [[file system]] used to hold files. Directories may also contain other directories. The {{code|cd}} command can be used to change into a subdirectory, move back into the parent directory, move all the way back to the [[root directory]] or move to any given directory. Consider the following subsection of a Unix filesystem, which shows a user's [[home directory]] (represented as {{code|~}}) with a file, {{code|text.txt}}, and three subdirectories. [[File:chdir example.png|center|framed|A user's view of the file system in Unix-like systems begins with the home directory (often abbreviated to {{code|~}}). From there, the tree can spread into more subdirectories and/or files.]] {{clear}} If the user's current working directory is the home directory ({{code|~}}), then entering the command [[ls]] followed by {{code|cd games}} might produce the following transcript: user@wikipedia:~$ ls workreports games encyclopedia text.txt user@wikipedia:~$ cd games user@wikipedia:~/games$ The user is now in the "games" directory. A similar session in DOS (though the concept of a "home directory" may not apply, depending on the specific version{{Vague|date=February 2011}}) would look like this: C:\> '''[[dir (command)|dir]]''' workreports Wed Oct 9th 9:01 games Tue Oct 8th 14:32 encyclopedia Mon Oct 1st 10:05 text txt 1903 Thu Oct10th 12:43 C:\> '''cd''' games C:\games> DOS maintains separate working directories for each [[Drive letter assignment|lettered drive]], and also has the concept of a current working drive. The {{code|cd}} command can be used to change the working directory of the working drive or another lettered drive. Typing the drive letter as a command on its own changes the working drive, e.g. {{code|C:}}; alternatively, {{code|cd}} with the {{code|/d}} switch may be used to change the working drive and that drive's working directory in one step. Modern versions of Windows simulate this behaviour for backwards compatibility under [[CMD.EXE]].[http://blogs.msdn.com/b/oldnewthing/archive/2010/10/11/10073890.aspx Why does each drive have its own current directory?] Note that executing {{code|cd}} from the command line with no arguments has different effects in different operating systems. For example, if {{code|cd}} is executed without arguments in DOS, OS/2, or Windows, the current [[working directory]] is displayed (equivalent to Unix [[pwd]]). If {{code|cd}} is executed without arguments in Unix, the user is returned to the home directory. Executing the {{code|cd}} command within a script or batch file also has different effects in different operating systems. In DOS, the caller's current directory can be directly altered by the [[batch file]]'s use of this command. In [[Unix]], the caller's current directory is not altered by the script's invocation of the {{code|cd}} command. This is because in Unix, the script is usually executed within a [[child process|subshell]]. {{code|cd}} is frequently included built directly into a command-line interpreter. This is the case in most of the [[Unix shell]]s ([[Bourne shell]], [[tcsh]], [[Bash (Unix shell)|bash]], etc.), [[cmd.exe]] and [[Windows PowerShell]] on Windows and [[COMMAND.COM]] on DOS. Command line shells on Windows usually use the [[Windows API]] to change the current working directory, whereas on Unix systems {{code|cd}} calls the {{code|chdir()}} [[POSIX]] [[C (programming language)|C]] function. This means that when the command is executed, no new process is created to migrate to the other directory as is the case with other commands such as [[ls]]. Instead, the shell itself executes this command. This is because, when a new [[Process (computing)|process]] is created, [[child process]] inherits the directory in which the [[parent process]] was created. If the {{code|cd}} command inherits the parent process' directory, then the objective of the command cd will never be achieved. [[Windows PowerShell]], Microsoft's object-oriented command line shell and [[scripting language]], executes the {{code|cd}} command (''cmdlet'') within the shell's process. However, since PowerShell is based on the [[.NET Framework]] and has a different architecture than previous shells, all of PowerShell's cmdlets like [[ls]], [[rm (Unix)|rm]] etc. run in the shell's process. Of course, this is not true for legacy commands which still run in a separate process. ==Options== ===Unix, Unix-like=== * {{code|cd}} by itself or {{code|cd ~}} will always put you in your home directory. * {{code|cd .}} will leave you in the same directory you are currently in (i.e. your current directory won't change). This can be useful if your shell's internal code can't deal with the directory you are in being recreated; running {{code|cd .}} will place your shell in the recreated directory. * {{code|cd ~username}} will put you in username's home directory. * {{code|cd dir}} (without a {{code|/}}) will put you in a subdirectory; for example, if you are in {{code|/usr}}, typing {{code|cd bin}} will put you in {{code|/usr/bin}}, while {{code|cd /bin}} puts you in {{code|/bin}}. * {{code|cd ..}} will move you up one directory. So, if you are {{code|/usr/bin/tmp}}, {{code|cd ..}} moves you to {{code|/usr/bin}}, while {{code|cd ../..}} moves you to {{code|/usr}} (i.e. up two levels). You can use this indirection to access subdirectories too. So, from {{code|/usr/bin/tmp}}, you can use {{code|cd ../../local}} to go to {{code|/usr/local}}. * {{code|cd -}} will switch you to the previous directory. For example, if you are in {{code|/usr/bin/tmp}}, and go to {{code|/etc}}, you can type {{code|cd -}} to go back to {{code|/usr/bin/tmp}}. You can use this to toggle back and forth between two directories. ===DOS, OS/2, Windows, ReactOS=== * ''no attributes'' print the full [[Path (computing)|path]] of the current directory. * {{code|-p}} Print the final directory stack, just like dirs.{{Where|Which OS? On Linux, cd -p outputs bash: cd: -p: invalid option whereas dirs outputs ~.|date=July 2011}} * {{code|-n}} Entries are wrapped before they reach the edge of the screen. {{Where|Which OS? cd -n outputs invalid option under Linux.|date=July 2011}} * {{code|-v}} entries are printed one per line, preceded by their stack positions. {{Where|Which OS? cd -v outputs invalid option under Linux.|date=July 2011}} * {{code|cd\}} (DOS and Windows only) returns to the root dir. Consequently, command {{code|cd\subdir}} always takes the user to the named subdirectory on the ''root directory'', regardless of where they are located when the command is issued. ==Interpreters other than an operating systems shell== In the [[File Transfer Protocol]], the respective command is spelled {{code|CWD}} in the control stream, but is available as {{code|cd}} in most [[client (computing)|client]] command-line programs. Some clients also have the {{code|lcd}} for changing the working directory '''l'''ocally. The command also pertains to command-line interpreters of various application software. ==See also== *[[Directory structure]] *[[pushd and popd]] *[[chroot]] *[[List of command-line interpreters]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [https://technet.microsoft.com/en-us/library/bb490875.aspx Windows XP > Command-line reference A-Z > Chdir (Cd)] from [[Microsoft TechNet]] * {{man|cu|cd|SUS|change the working directory}} {{Unix commands}} {{Windows commands}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Cd (Command)}} [[Category:Internal DOS commands]] [[Category:File system directories]] [[Category:OS/2 commands]] [[Category:Windows administration]] [[Category:Standard Unix programs]] [[Category:Unix SUS2008 utilities]]

revision.comment: Updated ownership data to reflect recent changes, additional investment.
revision.text:
{{Infobox company | name = Compare.com | logo = CompareLogo.jpg | logo_size = 250px | former_name = comparenow.com | type = [[Technology]] & [[Insurance]] | foundation = 2013 | location = [[Richmond, Virginia]], [[United States|USA]] | products = Auto Insurance Comparison | industry = [[Insurance]] | founders = Andrew Rose | homepage = https://www.compare.com | num_employees = 80 | parent = Admiral Group Plc }}
'''Compare.com''' (formerly '''Comparenow.com''') is a [[comparison shopping]] website for intangible products, most notably [[car insurance]], with headquarters in Richmond, VA. Compare.com is a sister company of [[Confused.com]], the United Kingdom's first car insurance comparison site, which is also owned by Admiral Group, plc.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.marketingmagazine.co.uk/article/1183890/confusedcom-overhauls-brand-search-expert-positioning |title=Confused.com overhauls brand in search of 'expert' positioning|date=2013-05-29 |accessdate=2015-03-26 |publisher=Marketing Magazine}}</ref> Insurance carriers on the compare.com panel are contractually obligated to honor the rate presented on compare.com’s site, as long as the user’s information is correctly entered. Compare.com charges the auto insurer on a cost-per-sale basis. <ref>{{cite news |url= http://www.richmond.com/business/economy/comparenow-trying-to-change-the-way-consumers-buy-auto-insurance/article_57df499e-b401-51c8-bcf0-53290da09af1.html |title=Comparenow trying to change the way consumers buy auto insurance |first=John Reid|last=Blackwell|date=2014-03-10 |accessdate=2014-05-11 |publisher=Richmond Times Dispatch}}</ref>
==History== Compare.com was launched in 2013, with the majority of its financial backing from [[Admiral Group]]. Other investors include [[Mapfre]], which owns 5.6% and [[White Mountains Insurance Group]], the former owners of [[Esurance]], which owns 18.4%. Diane Engelhardt, wife of former Admiral Group CEO [[Henry Engelhardt|Henry Englelhardt]], owns 17% as the result of an investment on November 1, 2018.<ref>{{cite news |url= http://www.insurancejournal.com/news/international/2016/03/03/400855.htm |title=Compare.com CEO Encouraged by Admiral Group's Record 2015 Profit |first=Don |last=Jergler |date=2016-03-03 |publisher=Insurance Journal}}</ref>
Compare.com's President and CEO, Andrew Rose, founder and former CEO of [[Elephant Insurance]], worked at [[Countrywide]] and [[Progressive Corporation|Progressive]] prior to launching compare.com .<ref>{{cite news |url= http://www.richmond.com/business/article_8c8174ed-afea-5093-a414-276239ebdd0a.html|title=Getting to know: Andrew Rose from Elephant Insurance|date=2011-05-28 |accessdate=2015-03-26 |publisher=Richmond Times Dispatch}}</ref> When compare.com began delivering quotes to customers, they did so with partnerships with five carriers.<ref>{{cite news |url= http://www.insurancejournal.com/news/international/2016/03/03/400855.htm |title=Compare.com CEO Encouraged by Admiral Group's Record 2015 Profit |first=Don |last=Jergler |date=2016-03-03 |publisher=Insurance Journal}}</ref> As of March 4, 2016, compare.com works with over 60 carriers to deliver more insurance comparisons to customers.<ref>{{cite news |url= http://www.insurancejournal.com/news/national/2015/03/10/360013.htm |title=Compare.com Confirms Partnership with Google Insurance Comparison Site |first=Amy |last=O'Connor |date=2015-03-15 |publisher=Insurance Journal}}</ref>
As of November 1, 2018 Compare.com has received $185 million dollars in total investment, making it one of the largest investments in the Insurtech category.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.richmond.com/business/local/henrico-based-compare-com-raised-million-to-expand-services-bringing/article_b643828b-2d2c-544a-a0b9-add66a36e889.html|title=Henrico-based Compare.com raised $35 million to expand services; bringing total investment to $185 million since 2013|last=Times-Dispatch|first=GREGORY J. GILLIGAN Richmond|work=Richmond Times-Dispatch|access-date=2018-11-09|language=en}}</ref>
== Relationship with Google ==
In January 2015, the New York Times revealed that Compare.com had formed a partnership with Google, offering them access to Compare.com’s panel of carriers in exchange for a share of the royalties paid by the carrier.<ref>{{cite news |url= http://bits.blogs.nytimes.com/2015/01/08/new-clues-on-googles-plans-for-insurance/ |title=New Clues on Google’s Plans for Insurance |first=Conor |last=Dougherty |date=2015-01-15 |accessdate=2015-03-19 |publisher=New York Times}}</ref> They join Coverhound<ref>{{cite news |url= http://marketingland.com/google-enters-auto-insurance-market-comparison-sites-react-agency-partner-raises-financing-120745|title=As Google Enters Auto Insurance Market, Comparison Sites React; Agency Partner Raises Financing |first=Ginny|last=Marvin|date=2015-03-10 |accessdate=2014-05-11 |publisher=Marketing Land}}</ref> and Bolt Solutions in partnering with Google's platform.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.insurancenetworking.com/news/news/bolt-and-comparecom-partner-with-google-compare-35695-1.html|title=Bolt and Compare.com Partner with Google Compare |first=Chris|last=McMahon|date=2015-03-24 |accessdate=2014-05-11 |publisher=Insurance Networking News}}</ref>
Compare.com worked with Google Compare for the duration of their existence in the American car insurance comparison market, until Google Compare announced that they will be withdrawing their service from the market.<ref>{{cite news | url= http://www.claimsjournal.com/news/international/2016/02/23/269005.htm | title= Google to Shut Down Online Insurance Site, Partners Say | first= Don | last= Jergler | date= 2016-02-23 | publisher=Claims Journal}}</ref>
==Operations== Compare.com operates under primary ownership of Admiral Group, Plc, which operates 14 brands in seven countries. Other companies owned by Admiral include: <ref>{{cite news | url= https://admiralgroup.co.uk/subsidiary-companies | title= Parent Company's Subsidiaries | publisher=Admiral Group plc}}</ref> * [[Confused.com]] (comparison website in the United Kingdom) * [[Admiral Insurance]] (insurance company in the United Kingdom) * [[Admiral Group|Diamond Insurance]] (insurance company for female drivers in the United Kingdom) * [[Elephant Insurance]] (insurance company in the United States) * Balumba (insurance company in Spain) * Qualitas Auto (insurance company in Spain) * Rastreator (comparison website in Spain) * Assicurazioni ConTe (insurance company in Italy) * L’olivier assurance auto (insurance company in France) * LeLynx (comparison website in France)
==National Advertising Campaign== In February 2016, compare.com began advertising their service nationally.<ref>{{cite news |url= http://www.richmond.com/business/local/article_85b338c8-3305-55a6-96b5-b030f4901505.html |title=Compare.com starts national ad campaign |first=John Reid |last=Blackwell |date=2016-02-12 |publisher=Richmond Times-Dispatch}}</ref> The advertising campaign features Agent Compare, who works in an underground facility to bring high-tech solutions to the auto insurance industry. Agent Compare promises to "Save Humanity from high insurance rates, one human at a time."
==References== {{reflist|2}}
[[Category:Comparison shopping websites]] [[Category:Companies based in Richmond, Virginia]] [[Category:Internet properties established in 2013]] [[Category:2013 establishments in Virginia]]

{{lead too short|date=July 2018}} {{refimprove|date=August 2016}} :''CSEL redirects here. For the Combat Survivor/Evader Locator of the U.S. military, see [[survival radio]].''
The '''''Corpus Scriptorum Ecclesiasticorum Latinorum''''' ('''CSEL''') is an academic series that publishes critical editions of Latin works by late-antique Christian authors.
== Description == The CSEL publishes Latin writings of Christian authors from the time of the late 2nd century ([[Tertullian]]) until the beginning of the 8th century ([[Bede]] the Venerable, †735). Each text is edited on the basis of all (or the most important of all) the extant manuscripts according to modern [[Textual criticism|editorial techniques]], in order to produce a text as close as possible to the original. Each volume includes an introduction, in which the principles of the preparation of the text are explained. Some editions are prepared by the [http://csel.sbg.ac.at/en/personen/ staff of the CSEL], others by external, internationally renowned experts; the volumes are published after a positive evaluation by an international advisory board; the publisher is [[De Gruyter]]<ref>[http://www.degruyter.com/view/serial/432120 Corpus Scriptorum Ecclesiasticorum Latinorum]</ref> (prior to 2012: Verlag der Österreichischen Akademie der Wissenschaften). The CSEL also runs the online database [http://csel.sbg.ac.at/en/hilfsmittel/edenda/ Edenda],<ref>[http://csel.sbg.ac.at/en/hilfsmittel/edenda/ CSEL – Corpus Scriptorum Ecclesiasticorum Latinorum]</ref> where CSEL editions as well as editing projects by others are publicly announced. In addition, the CSEL publishes special catalogues for the large extant corpus of medieval manuscripts containing works of Augustine or ascribed to him ("Die handschriftliche Überlieferung der Werke des heiligen Augustinus"), in order to make time-consuming research in this field easier. In addition, monographs on topics related to the Latin patristic period and conference proceedings are published at irregular intervals ("[http://csel.sbg.ac.at/en/publikationen/extra-seriem/ CSEL Extra seriem]").<ref>http://csel.sbg.ac.at/en/publikationen/extra-seriem/</ref>
== History == The CSEL was founded in 1864 by the Imperial Academy of Sciences in Vienna (Österreichische Akademie der Wissenschaften) in order to produce critical editions of Latin patristic texts – editions that were meant to facilitate the lexicographical work of the Thesaurus linguae Latinae (at that time still in the planning stages).<ref>http://csel.sbg.ac.at/en/profil/geschichte/</ref> Before the year 2012 the CSEL was edited by the “Kommission zur Herausgabe des Corpus der lateinischen Kirchenväter” (“Kirchenväterkommission”) of the [[Austrian Academy of Sciences]]. The chairmen of this commission were:<ref>Weber, 150 Jahre Corpus Scriptorum Ecclesiasticorum Latinorum, X</ref> * 1864–1874: Johannes Vahlen * 1875–1891: Franz von Miklosich * 1891–1907: Wilhelm von Hartel * 1907–1916: Wilhelm Meyer-Lübke * 1916–1941: Edmund Hauler * 1941–1963: Richard Meister * 1964–1982: Rudolf Hanslik * 1982–1991: Herbert Hunger * 1991–2001: Adolf Primmer * 2001–2012: Kurt Smolak After the commission was transferred to the [[University of Salzburg]] in 2012, the CSEL became part of the Department of Ancient Studies / Latin at the University of Salzburg.
== Evaluation and controversy == The series currently consists of about 100 [http://csel.sbg.ac.at/en/publikationen/csel/ volumes], some with multiple sub-volumes.<ref>http://csel.sbg.ac.at/en/publikationen/csel/</ref> These volumes have replaced about a third of J. P. Migne’s [[Patrologia Latina]], which do not offer critical editions. Some CSEL volumes have themselves been replaced by more recent critical editions (e.g., [[Corpus Christianorum]] Series Latina, [[Sources chrétiennes]], [[Bibliothèque augustinienne]]), but about two-thirds of them are still considered authoritative standard editions; in fact, the CSEL edition often remains the only critical edition of a given text. In the course of work on the manuscript catalogues as well as on the preparation of CSEL editions, patristic texts which were previously thought lost have been recovered: e.g., the writings of the Spanish heretic [[Priscillian]],<ref>CSEL 18, Wien 1889, ed. Georg Schepps</ref> the commentary on Revelation by [[Victorinus of Pettau]],<ref>CSEL 49, Wien 1916, ed. Johannes Haussleiter</ref> 29 unknown letters of [[Augustine]] ("Epistulae Divjak"),<ref>CSEL 88, Wien 1981, ed. Johannes Divjak</ref> six of Augustine’s sermons ("Sermones Erfurt"),<ref>Wiener Studien 121 (2008), 227-284 und 122 (2009), 171-213, edd. Isabella Schiller, Dorothea Weber, Clemens Weidmann</ref> and the full text of the commentary on the gospels by [[Fortunatianus of Aquileia]] (mid-4th century; edition published 2017). Numerous volumes of the CSEL were incorporated into the digital [[Library of Latin Texts]] (LLT).
== Literature == * Rudolf Hanslik, 100 Jahre Corpus Scriptorum Ecclesiasticorum Latinorum, in: Anzeiger der philosophisch-historischen Klasse der Österreichischen Akademie der Wissenschaften 101 (1964), 21-35. * Michaela Zelzer, Ein Jahrhundert (und mehr) CSEL. Evaluation von Ziel und Veröffentlichungen, Sacris Erudiri 38 (1998), 75-99. * Dorothea Weber, 150 Jahre Corpus Scriptorum Ecclesiasticorum Latinorum, in: Edition und Erforschung lateinischer patristischer Texte. 150 Jahre CSEL (FS Kurt Smolak), herausgegeben von Victoria Zimmerl-Panagl, Lukas J. Dorfbauer, Clemens Weidmann, Berlin 2014, IX-XI.
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[http://csel.sbg.ac.at/en CSEL] (official page, including a [http://csel.sbg.ac.at/en/publikationen/csel/ list of volumes] and authors). *[http://www.earlymedievalmonasticism.org/Corpus-Scriptorum-Ecclesiasticorum-Latinorum.html Links to vol. 1-55 on archive.org (with direct links to each text).] *[http://www.roger-pearse.com/weblog/2009/10/24/list-of-csel-volumes-at-google-books/ List of CSEL volumes at Google Books]. *[https://web.archive.org/web/20101029025007/http://fourthcentury.com/index.php/csel-on-internet Most of the early volumes are available on Google books, here is a list.] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20080620085012/http://www.fourthcentury.com/ More information on 4th century Christianity]. *An open source XML version of CSEL public domain volumes has been made available by the [https://opengreekandlatin.github.io/csel-dev/ Open Greek and Latin Project] at the University of Leipzig.
[[Category:Series of books]] [[Category:Publications of patristic texts]]

page.title: Country code top-level domains with commercial licenses

revision.comment: /* List of ccTLDs permitting worldwide commercial use */Revert accidental junk
revision.text:
'''Country code top-level domains with commercial licenses''' are [[Internet]] [[country code top-level domain]] that have adopted a policy for worldwide commercial use.
Some of the world's smallest countries have opened their country code domain to worldwide registrations for commercial purposes. For example, [[Tuvalu]] and the [[Federated States of Micronesia]], small island-states in the Pacific, have partnered with [[VeriSign]] and FSM Telecommunications respectively, to sell domain name registrations using the <tt>[[.tv|TV]]</tt> and <tt>[[.fm|fm]]</tt> TLDs to television and radio stations.
Some commercially available ccTLDs are in demand for use outside their home countries because their name can provide a component of a meaningful word or phrase. These are sometimes referred to as vanity ccTLDs.
==List of ccTLDs permitting worldwide commercial use== * [[.ac|<tt>ac</tt>]] ([[Ascension Island]]) is sometimes used to stand for "Access Connection" or "Access Card". It is occasionally used by universities to stand for "academic", for example by the [[University of Kurdistan – Hawler]] (<tt>ukh.ac</tt>) or [[Ralston College]] (<tt>ralston.ac</tt>), * [[.ad|<tt>ad</tt>]] ([[Andorra]]) has recently been increasingly used by advertising agencies or [[classified advertising]]. * [[.ag|<tt>ag</tt>]] ([[Antigua and Barbuda]]) is sometimes used for agricultural sites. In [[Germany]] and German-speaking countries, AG (short for [[Aktiengesellschaft]]) is appended to the name of a stock-based company, similar to [[Incorporation (business)|Inc.]] in [[United States|USA]]. * [[.am|<tt>am</tt>]] ([[Armenia]]) is often used for [[AM broadcasting|AM]] radio stations, or for [[domain hack]]s. * [[.as|<tt>as</tt>]] ([[American Samoa]]) In Estonia, Denmark and Norway, [[Aksjeselskap|AS]] is appended to the name of a stock-based company, similar to Inc. in USA. In Czech Republic and Slovakia, the joint stock corporation a.s. abbreviation stands for [[:cs:Akciová společnost]]. * [[.at|<tt>at</tt>]] ([[Austria]]) is used for English words ending in "at". * [[.be|<tt>be</tt>]] ([[Belgium]]) is sometimes used for the literal term "be". It is also used in some download sites as the end of the word "tube" such as <tt>downloadyoutu.be</tt>, a site for the downloading of [[YouTube]] videos. YouTube site is accessible through <tt>youtu.be</tt> domain, registered by [[Google]] itself.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://youtube-global.blogspot.com/2009/12/make-way-for-youtube-links.html |title=YouTube Blog: Make Way for youtu.be Links |publisher=Youtube-global.blogspot.com |date=2009-12-21 |accessdate=2012-07-15}}</ref> * [[.by|<tt>by</tt>]] ([[Belarus]]) is sometimes used in Germany, as "BY" is the official abbreviation of the state [[Bavaria|Bayern]]. * [[.ca|<tt>ca</tt>]] ([[Canada]]) is occasionally used to create domain hacks like <tt>histori.ca</tt>, the web domain of [[The Historica Dominion Institute]]. This type of use is limited by the .ca domain's Canadian residence requirements. * [[.cc|<tt>cc</tt>]] ([[Cocos (Keeling) Islands]]) is used for a wide variety of sites such as community colleges, especially before such institutions were allowed to use .edu. It is also used by some churches as an abbreviation of Christian church. For example, www.gracechurch.cc, www.bible.cc, www.saintjohns.cc * [[.cd|<tt>cd</tt>]] ([[Democratic Republic of Congo]]) is used for CD merchants and file sharing sites. * [[.ch|<tt>ch</tt>]] ([[Switzerland]]) is used for a number of church websites.<ref>For example, eaglesnest.ch in Delaware or stmichaels.ch in Bristol.</ref> * [[.ck|<tt>ck</tt>]] ([[Cook Islands]]) was notably abused in [[Chris Morris (satirist)|Chris Morris's]] [[Nathan Barley]] by preceding it with ".co" in order to spell out the word "cock" (.co.ck as in <tt>trashbat.co.ck</tt>). * [[.co|<tt>co</tt>]] ([[Colombia]]) is marketed as commercial, corporation, or company.<ref name="unique">{{cite web |url=http://www.cointernet.co/frequently-asked-questions |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-03-13 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110707052545/http://www.cointernet.co/frequently-asked-questions |archivedate=2011-07-07 |df= }} What makes .CO such a unique opportunity?</ref> * [[.dj|<tt>dj</tt>]] ([[Djibouti]]) is used for CD merchants and [[disc jockies]] (DJs, as in deejay). * [[.es|<tt>es</tt>]] ([[Spain]]) is used for forming plural words (e.g. in English <tt>beach.es</tt>). * [[.fi|<tt>fi</tt>]] ([[Finland]]) is used as a domain hack by [[Eye-Fi]] (<tt>eye.fi</tt>), a maker of memory cards with Wi-Fi capabilities. * [[.fm|<tt>fm</tt>]] (the [[Federated States of Micronesia]]) is often used for [[FM broadcasting|FM]] radio stations (and even non-FM stations, such as [[internet radio]] stations). * [[.gl|<tt>gl</tt>]] (Greenland) is often used for [[Galician language|Galician]] or [[Galicia (Spain)|Galicia]]-related sites, in waiting for the [[.gal|<tt>gal</tt>]] domain. This TLD is also used by Google's link shortening and analytics service [[Goo.gl]]. * [[.gg|<tt>gg</tt>]] ([[Guernsey]]) is often used by the gaming and gambling industry, particularly in relation to horse racing and online poker. * [[.im|<tt>im</tt>]] (the [[Isle of Man]]) is often used by [[instant messaging]] programs and services. * [[.in|<tt>in</tt>]] ([[India]]) is widely used in the internet industry. * [[.io|<tt>io</tt>]] (the [[British Indian Ocean Territory]]). Notable examples are online storage site [[Drop.io]] and task list site Done.io. Commonly used by tech companies or individuals for its relation to [[Input/Output]]. * [[.is|<tt>is</tt>]] ([[Iceland]]) is used as the English verb, "to be" in conjunction with a directory name suffix to complete a linguistically correct sentence (for example, "<noun>.is/<verb>" or "<noun>.is/<adjective>). * [[.ir|<tt>ir</tt>]] ([[Iran]]) is used in domain hacks (e.g. .has.ir). * [[.it|<tt>it</tt>]] ([[Italy]]) is the third-person neuter pronoun in English and is used for domains such as <tt>win.at.it</tt>. * [[.je|<tt>je</tt>]] ([[Jersey]]) is often used as a diminutive in Dutch (e.g. "huis.je"), as "your" ("zoek.je" = "search your"), or as "I" in French (e.g. "moi.je"). * [[.la|<tt>la</tt>]] ([[Laos]]) is marketed as suggesting [[Los Angeles]] or [[Latin America]]. * [[.li|<tt>li</tt>]] ([[Liechtenstein]]) is marketed as meaning [[Long Island]]. * [[.lv|<tt>lv</tt>]] ([[Latvia]]) is also used to abbreviate [[Las Vegas Valley|Las Vegas]] or less frequently, [[love]]. * [[.ly|<tt>ly</tt>]] ([[Libya]]) is also used for words ending with [[suffix]] "ly". * [[.md|<tt>md</tt>]] ([[Moldova]]) is marketed to the medical industry (as in "medical domain"{{Citation needed|date=December 2010}} or "medical doctor"). * [[.me|<tt>me</tt>]] ([[Montenegro]]) was opened in 2008,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dnxpert.com/2008/04/09/registrars-preparing-for-the-me-extension/ |title=article and roll out schedule for TLD .me |publisher=Dnxpert.com |date=2008-04-09 |accessdate=2012-07-15}}</ref> and has quickly become one of the most used ccTLDs for vanity. It is used worldwide by individuals, and companies offering services, because of the meaning in English and more languages. It is widely used as well in the Middle East for its abbreviation. * [[.mn|<tt>mn</tt>]] ([[Mongolia]]) is used to abbreviate [[Minnesota]]. * [[.ms|<tt>ms</tt>]] ([[Montserrat]]) is also used for some [[Microsoft]]-related projects. * [[.mu|<tt>mu</tt>]] ([[Mauritius]]) is used within the music industry. * [[.ni|<tt>ni</tt>]] ([[Nicaragua]]) is occasionally adopted by companies from [[Northern Ireland]], particularly to distinguish from the more usual [[.uk]] within all parts of the [[United Kingdom]]. * [[.nu|<tt>nu</tt>]] ([[Niue]]) is marketed as resembling "new" in English and "now" in Scandinavian/Dutch. Also means "nude" in French and Portuguese. * [[.pr|<tt>pr</tt>]] ([[Puerto Rico]]) can be used in the meaning of "Public Relations". * [[.rs|<tt>rs</tt>]] ([[Serbia]]) is marketed in English words ending with the letters "rs" such as <tt>www.blogge.rs</tt>. * [[.sc|<tt>sc</tt>]] ([[Seychelles]]) is often used as .Source . * [[.sh|<tt>sh</tt>]] ([[Saint Helena]]) is also sometimes used for entities connected to the [[Germany|German]] ''[[States of Germany|Bundesland]]'' of [[Schleswig-Holstein]] or the [[Swiss]] [[Cantons of Switzerland|Canton]] of [[Canton of Schaffhausen|Schaffhausen]], or to [[Shanghai]] or [[Shenzen]] in China<!-- http://www.google.com/search?hl=sv&q=site:.sh finds mostly Chinese sites-->. * [[.si|<tt>si</tt>]] ([[Slovenia]]) is also used by Hispanic sites as "yes" ("sí"). Mexican mayor candidate Jorge Arana, for example, had his web site registered as <tt>www.jorgearana.si</tt> (i.e. "Jorge Arana, sí", meaning "Jorge Arana, yes"). * [[.sr|<tt>sr</tt>]] ([[Suriname]]) is marketed in the USA as being for "seniors".{{citation needed|date=November 2010}} * [[.st|<tt>st</tt>]] ([[São Tomé and Príncipe]]) is being marketed worldwide as an abbreviation for various things including "street". * [[.tc|<tt>tc</tt>]] ([[Turks and Caicos Islands]]) is marketed as "abbreviation of Türkiye Cumhuriyeti".<ref name="dottc">http://www.tc</ref> * [[.tm|<tt>tm</tt>]] ([[Turkmenistan]]) can be used as "trade mark". * [[.to|<tt>to</tt>]] ([[Tonga]]) is often used as the English word "to", like <tt>go.to</tt>. Also is marketed as the TLD for [[Toronto]] and for the Italian city and province of [[Turin]] (Torino in Italian). * [[.tv|<tt>TV</tt>]] ([[Tuvalu]]) is used for the television/entertainment industry purposes. It is also used for local businesses in the province of [[Province of Treviso|Treviso]], Italy. * [[.vc|<tt>vc</tt>]] ([[Saint Vincent and the Grenadines]]) is sometimes used to abbreviate "Venture Capital" "Vacation Club" or "Virtual Casino". * [[.vg|<tt>vg</tt>]] ([[British Virgin Islands]]) is sometimes used to abbreviate [[Video game]]s. * [[.vu|<tt>vu</tt>]] ([[Vanuatu]]) means "seen" in French as well as an abbreviation for the English language word "view". * [[.ws|<tt>ws</tt>]] ([[Samoa]], earlier Western Samoa) is marketed as .Website.
== See also == * [[Country code top-level domain]] * [[gccTLD|Generic Country Code Top Level Domain (GccTLD)]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Country Code Top-Level Domains with commercial licenses}} [[Category:Top-level domains]] [[Category:Country codes]] [[Category:Domain name system]]

revision.text:
The '''Current Procedural Terminology''' ('''CPT''') code set is a [[medical coding|medical code set]] maintained by the [[American Medical Association]] through the CPT Editorial Panel.<ref>[http://www.ama-assn.org/ama/pub/physician-resources/solutions-managing-your-practice/coding-billing-insurance/cpt/cpt-process-faq/code-becomes-cpt.page AMA (CPT) CPT Process] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160511115308/http://www.ama-assn.org/ama/pub/physician-resources/solutions-managing-your-practice/coding-billing-insurance/cpt/cpt-process-faq/code-becomes-cpt.page |date=May 11, 2016 }}</ref> The CPT code set (copyright protected by the AMA) describes medical, surgical, and diagnostic services and is designed to communicate uniform information about medical services and procedures among physicians, coders, patients, accreditation organizations, and payers for administrative, financial, and analytical purposes.
New editions are released each October.<ref name="Durham2008">{{cite book|author=Laura Southard Durham|title=Lippincott Williams and Wilkins' Administrative Medical Assisting|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=b9NyTDdaEEsCandpg=RA2-PA102|accessdate=26 May 2011|date=1 June 2008|publisher=Lippincott Williams and Wilkins|isbn=978-0-7817-9789-4|pages=2–}}</ref> The current version is the CPT 2018. It is available in both a standard edition and a professional edition.<ref name="AbrahamAhlman2010">{{cite book|author1=Michelle Abraham|author2=Jay T. Ahlman|author3=Angela J. Boudreau |author4=Judy L. Connelly |author5=Desiree D. Evans |author6=Rejina L Glenn|title=CPT 2011 Standard Edition|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=vZv5RQAACAAJ|accessdate=26 May 2011|date=30 October 2010|publisher=American Medical Association Press|isbn=978-1-60359-216-1}}</ref><ref name="Association(COR)2010">{{cite book|author1=American Medical Association|author2=American Medical Association (COR)|author3=Michelle Abraham |author4=Jay T. Ahlman |author5=Angela J. Boudreau |author6=Judy L. Connelly|title=CPT 2011 Professional Edition|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-FP1RQAACAAJ|accessdate=26 May 2011|date=30 October 2010|publisher=American Medical Association Press|isbn=978-1-60359-217-8}}</ref>
CPT coding is similar to [[ICD-9]] and [[ICD-10]] coding, except that it identifies the services rendered, rather than the diagnosis on the claim (ICD-10-CM was created for diagnostic coding- it took the place of Volume 3 of the ICD-9). The ICD code sets also contain procedure codes ([[ICD-10 Procedure Coding System|ICD-10-PCS codes]]), but these are only used in the [[inpatient]] setting.<ref>{{cite journal|title=Overview of inpatient coding |journal=American Journal of Health-System Pharmacy |date=1 November 2003 |first=Sherri, Pharm.D. |last=Alexander |volume=60 |url=http://www.ashp.org/s_ashp/docs/files/Suppl6_Alexander.pdf |accessdate=30 April 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120917102527/https://www.ashp.org/s_ashp/docs/files/Suppl6_Alexander.pdf |archivedate=17 September 2012 |df= }}</ref>
CPT is currently identified by the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services (CMS)<ref name="cms.hhs">[http://www.cms.hhs.gov/ Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150720142115/http://www.cms.hhs.gov/ |date=July 20, 2015 }}</ref> as Level 1 of the [[Healthcare Common Procedure Coding System]].
The Current Procedural Terminology (CPT) was developed by the American Medical Association (AMA).<ref name="cms.hhs" />
==Types of code== There are three types of CPT code: Category I, Category II, and Category III.
===Category I=== Category I CPT Code(s). There are six main sections:<ref name="Moisio2009">{{cite book|author=Marie A. Moisio|title=Medical Terminology for Insurance and Coding|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=HjYEikV_n6MCandpg=PA80|accessdate=26 May 2011|date=8 April 2009|publisher=Cengage Learning|isbn=978-1-4283-0426-0|pages=80–}}</ref>
====Codes for evaluation and management: 99201–99499==== * (99201–99215) [[Outpatient|Office/other outpatient services]] * (99217–99220) [[Medical observation|Hospital observation]] services * (99221–99239) [[Inpatient|Hospital inpatient]] services * (99241–99255) [[Consultation (doctor)|Consultations]] * (99281–99288) [[Emergency department]] services * (99291–99292) [[Intensive care medicine|Critical care]] services * (99304–99318) [[Nursing facility]] services * (99324–99337) Domiciliary, rest home ([[nursing home|boarding home]]) or custodial care services * (99339–99340) Domiciliary, rest home ([[assisted living facility]]), or home care plan oversight services * (99341–99350) [[home care|Home health]] services * (99354–99360) Prolonged services * (99363–99368) [[Medical case management|Case management]] services * (99374–99380) Care plan oversight services * (99381–99429) [[Preventive medicine]] services * (99441–99444) [[Telemedicine|Non-face-to-face physician services]] * (99450–99456) Special evaluation and management services * (99460–99465) [[Neonatal care|Newborn care]] services * (99466–99480) [[NICU|Inpatient neonatal intensive, and pediatric/neonatal critical, care services]] * (99487–99489) [https://www.supercoder.com/cpt-codes-range/2959 Complex chronic care coordination] services * (99495–99496) [[Transitional care]] management services * (99499) Other evaluation and management services

===Category II=== CPT II codes describe clinical components usually included in evaluation and management or clinical services and are not associated with any relative value. Category II codes are reviewed by the Performance Measures Advisory Group (PMAG), an advisory body to the CPT Editorial Panel and the CPT/HCPAC Advisory Committee. The PMAG is composed of performance measurement experts representing the Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality (AHRQ), the American Medical Association (AMA), the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services (CMS), the Joint Commission on Accreditation of Healthcare Organizations (JCAHO), the National Committee for Quality Assurance (NCQA) and the Physician Consortium for Performance Improvement. The PMAG may seek additional expertise and/or input from other national health care organizations, as necessary, for the development of Category II codes. These may include national medical specialty societies, other national health care professional associations, accrediting bodies and federal regulatory agencies.
Category II codes make use of an alphabetical character as the 5th character in the string (i.e., 4 digits followed by the letter F). These digits are not intended to reflect the placement of the code in the regular (Category I) part of the CPT codebook. Appendix H in CPT section contains information about performance measurement exclusion of modifiers, measures, and the measures' source(s). Currently there are 11 Category II codes. They are:
* (0001F-0015F) Composite measures * (0500F-0584F) Patient management * (1000F-1505F) Patient history * (2000F-2060F) Physical examination * (3006F-3776F) Diagnostic/screening processes or results * (4000F-4563F) Therapeutic, preventive or other interventions * (5005F-5250F) Follow-up or other outcomes * (6005F-6150F) Patient safety * (7010F-7025F) Structural Measures * (9001F-9007F) Non-Measure Claims Based Reporting
CPT II codes are billed in the procedure code field, just as CPT Category I codes are billed. Because CPT II codes are not associated with any relative value, they are billed with a $0.00 billable charge amount.<ref>AMA coding manual</ref>
===Category III=== * Category III CPT Code(s) – Emerging technology (Category III codes: 0016T-0207T<ref>CPT 2010</ref>)
==Major psychotherapy revisions== The CPT code revisions that affect counselors are simple and straightforward. Here is a list of psychotherapy CPT codes that will be retired, and their 2013 comparables:
90801 –> \ Family therapy codes (90847 and 90846) will remain unchanged, as will codes for psychological testing.<ref>{{cite web|last=Centore|first=Anthony|title=2013 CPT Code Revisions|url=http://thriveworks.com/blog/2013-cpt-code-revisions-what-the-changes-mean-for-counselors/|publisher=Thriveworks.com|accessdate=6 February 2013}}</ref>
==Criticism of copyright== CPT is a registered trademark of the American Medical Association. The AMA holds the copyright for the CPT coding system.<ref>[http://www.ama-assn.org/ama/pub/physician-resources/solutions-managing-your-practice/coding-billing-insurance/cpt/cpt-products-services/licensing.page AMA (CPT) CPT Licensing] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161021071833/http://www.ama-assn.org/ama/pub/physician-resources/solutions-managing-your-practice/coding-billing-insurance/cpt/cpt-products-services/licensing.page |date=October 21, 2016 }}</ref> However, in [[Practice Management v. American Medical Association|''Practice Management v. American Medical Association'']]<ref>{{cite web|url=https://scholar.google.com/scholar_case?case=17818566471505625329|title=Practice Management Info. v. American Medical Ass'n, 121 F. 3d 516 - Court of Appeals, 9th Circuit 1997|last=|first=|date=|website=|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161021071020/https://cyber.harvard.edu/people/tfisher/IP/1997%20PMI%20Abridged.pdf|archivedate=2016-10-21|deadurl=no|accessdate=2016-10-20|df=}}</ref> the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit held that while the AMA owned the copyright, it could not enjoin a competitor on the basis that the AMA had misused its copyright.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Pamela|first=Samuelson,|date=2007|title=Questioning Copyrights in Standards|url=https://lawdigitalcommons.bc.edu/bclr/vol48/iss1/8/|journal=Boston College Law Review|language=en|volume=48|issue=1}}</ref> Practice Management had argued that the publication of the CPT into federal regulation invalidated the copyright; the general debate around copyright and regulation access was revived in 2012<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Contreras|first=Jorge|date=2013-04-10|title=Technical Standards and Bioinformatics|url=https://papers.ssrn.com/sol3/papers.cfm?abstract_id=2313788|journal=|language=en|volume=BIOINFORMATICS LAW|pages=|via=}}</ref> by a petition motivated by a [[Administrative Conference of the United States]] recommendation.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.acus.gov/sites/default/files/Recommendation-2011-5-Incorporation-by-Reference.pdf|title=Administrative Conference Recommendation 2011-5 Incorporation by Reference Adopted December 8, 2011|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=[[Administrative Conference of the United States]]|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180531200809/https://www.acus.gov/sites/default/files/Recommendation-2011-5-Incorporation-by-Reference.pdf|archive-date=2018-05-31|dead-url=no|access-date=2018-05-31}}</ref>
Despite the copyrighted nature of the CPT code sets, the use of the code is mandated by almost all health insurance payment and information systems, including the [[Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services]] (CMS) and [[HIPAA]], and the data for the code sets appears in the [[Federal Register]]. As a result, it is necessary for most users of the CPT code (principally providers of services) to pay license fees for access to the code.<ref>http://www.ama-assn.org/ama1/pub/upload/mm/37/2009-annual-report.pdf{{Dead link|date=November 2013}}</ref>
===Limited CPT search offered by the AMA=== The AMA offers a limited search of the CPT manual for personal, non-commercial use on its web site.<ref name="amasearch">AMA (2012). "cpt® Code/Relative Value Search". Retrieved from {{cite web|url=https://ocm.ama-assn.org/OCM/CPTRelativeValueSearch.do |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-07-06 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160326031927/https://ocm.ama-assn.org/OCM/CPTRelativeValueSearch.do |archivedate=2016-03-26 |df= }}.</ref>
